questions.claim: The government has officially passed a national "real-name" rule requiring every social media profile to publicly display the user's real name.
questions.explanation: This is a common misinterpretation. Proposed identity verification policies target account creation verification on the backend, not mandatory public display for all users.

questions.claim: A presidential candidate promised to eliminate all personal income taxes during a debate.
questions.explanation: The widely shared clip was edited. The full statement discussed simplifying brackets and increasing credits for specific brackets rather than abolishing all income taxes.

questions.claim: A city council secretly approved a plan to sell all public parks to private developers.
questions.explanation: Land sales of public parks require formal hearings and public records. Meeting minutes show only a feasibility study authorization, not a sale.

questions.claim: The national election date was moved forward by two weeks without any parliamentary vote.
questions.explanation: Changing a federal election date requires legal procedures and announcements. No official notice or legislative action corroborates the claim.

questions.claim: A foreign government purchased the voter database for the entire country.
questions.explanation: Voter rolls are regulated by domestic laws and are not sold to foreign governments. Public versions exist but exclude sensitive personal data.

questions.claim: The legislature passed a law making it illegal to criticize public officials online.
questions.explanation: Defamation and harassment laws exist, but political criticism remains protected speech. The referenced bill targeted coordinated doxxing and threats, not general criticism.

questions.claim: A viral photo shows the legislature voting at 3 a.m. without any public notice.
questions.explanation: Late-night sessions happen, but meeting schedules and agendas are typically posted in advance; the photo is from an unrelated night-shift security drill.

questions.claim: The national constitution was secretly amended last week without a public vote or debate.
questions.explanation: Constitutional amendments require formal procedures with recorded debates and public records; no such records exist for last week.

questions.claim: A minister said in an interview that journalists who spread 'fake news' should be jailed.
questions.explanation: A clipped reel removed the preceding clarification about existing defamation laws; the minister did not call for jailing journalists broadly.

questions.claim: All protest permits were suspended nationwide for the next six months.
questions.explanation: Permit policies are local. No nationwide moratorium has been enacted; isolated suspensions may occur for safety or special events.

questions.claim: Most democracies conduct independent audits or recount processes to verify election results.
questions.explanation: Post-election audits and recounts are standard safeguards designed to verify tabulation accuracy and strengthen public confidence.

questions.claim: Freedom of Information laws in many countries allow citizens to request government records, subject to limited exemptions.
questions.explanation: FOI/FOIA regimes create a formal process for record requests while protecting sensitive areas like personal data and national security.

questions.claim: Amending a national constitution generally requires formal procedures that are public and recorded.
questions.explanation: Constitutional change typically involves supermajorities, referenda, or multiple readings, with official minutes and records.

questions.claim: Campaign finance regulations commonly require candidates or parties to disclose donors above certain thresholds.
questions.explanation: Disclosure thresholds aim to increase transparency while balancing privacy for small donors.

questions.claim: Parliamentary debates are usually recorded in official transcripts that are publicly accessible.
questions.explanation: Hansard-style records document proceedings for accountability and historical reference.

questions.claim: Vitamin C megadoses can cure the common cold.
questions.explanation: Evidence shows vitamin C may slightly reduce duration in some cases but does not cure colds; prevention and symptomatic care remain standard.

questions.claim: Essential oils can reverse late-stage cancer.
questions.explanation: No credible clinical trials demonstrate reversal of advanced cancers with essential oils. Standard oncology treatments are evidence-based.

questions.claim: Detox foot pads pull heavy metals and 'toxins' out of your body overnight.
questions.explanation: Color changes are due to pad ingredients reacting to moisture; there is no credible evidence of toxin extraction via skin.

questions.claim: Raw garlic can replace antibiotics for serious infections.
questions.explanation: While compounds show lab activity, clinical dosing and safety for treating serious infections are unproven; delaying care is risky.

questions.claim: Melatonin gummies are harmless for children because they are 'natural'.
questions.explanation: Melatonin affects sleep-wake cycles; dosing and quality vary. Parents should follow medical advice rather than assume universal safety.

questions.claim: You can fully 'reset' your metabolism in 7 days using a specific diet.
questions.explanation: Short-term diets may change water weight and glycogen, but do not permanently reset basal metabolic rate.

questions.claim: Alkaline water cures acid reflux by changing blood pH.
questions.explanation: Drinking water has minimal effect on tightly regulated blood pH; reflux management involves multiple lifestyle and medical factors.

questions.claim: Taking antibiotics 'just in case' helps with viral colds.
questions.explanation: Antibiotics do not treat viruses and unnecessary use increases side effects and resistance.

questions.claim: Copper bracelets reliably reduce arthritis inflammation.
questions.explanation: Placebo-controlled studies show no consistent anti-inflammatory effect beyond placebo.

questions.claim: Daily multivitamins eliminate the need for a balanced diet.
questions.explanation: Supplements can address deficiencies but cannot replace the benefits of varied whole foods, fiber, and overall dietary patterns.

questions.claim: Vaccines must pass phased clinical trials for safety and efficacy before regulatory approval.
questions.explanation: Phases I–III assess safety, dosing, and effectiveness; post-marketing surveillance continues monitoring.

questions.claim: Overuse and misuse of antibiotics contribute to antimicrobial resistance.
questions.explanation: Selective pressure allows resistant strains to proliferate, reducing future treatment options.

questions.claim: Regular physical activity lowers the risk of cardiovascular disease.
questions.explanation: Exercise improves blood pressure, lipid profiles, insulin sensitivity, and overall vascular health.

questions.claim: People with Type 1 diabetes require insulin therapy to manage blood glucose.
questions.explanation: Type 1 diabetes involves autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells, necessitating exogenous insulin.

questions.claim: Cigarette smoking significantly increases the risk of lung cancer.
questions.explanation: Tobacco smoke contains carcinogens that cause DNA damage and promote malignant transformation.

questions.claim: Incognito mode hides your browsing from your ISP.
questions.explanation: Private browsing prevents local history storage but does not conceal traffic from your employer or internet provider.

questions.claim: Charging your phone overnight ruins the battery immediately.
questions.explanation: Modern devices manage charging to prevent continuous overcharge; long-term heat and cycles affect degradation, not a single overnight charge.

questions.claim: Clearing your browser cookies once guarantees websites cannot track you afterwards.
questions.explanation: Websites can use many identifiers beyond cookies, such as IP, local storage, or device fingerprinting.

questions.claim: 5G towers inherently cause phones to drain battery much faster even when idle.
questions.explanation: Battery life depends on signal quality and device behavior; 5G itself is not a constant drain when idle.

questions.claim: End-to-end encryption lets platform employees read your private messages.
questions.explanation: With true end-to-end encryption, only communicating devices hold keys; platforms can access metadata but not content.

questions.claim: If a photo is on the internet, it is legal to reuse it anywhere.
questions.explanation: Online availability does not waive copyright; licensing or fair use applies case by case.

questions.claim: More megapixels always mean better image quality on phones.
questions.explanation: Sensor size, optics, and processing often matter more than pixel count alone.

questions.claim: Turning on airplane mode completely disables all location tracking.
questions.explanation: Some devices may still collect or infer location from cached data; airplane mode reduces radios but is not a privacy guarantee.

questions.claim: Private browsing mode hides your activity from your employer or ISP.
questions.explanation: Incognito prevents local history but does not hide traffic from networks or providers.

questions.claim: Clearing app cache will permanently speed up your phone.
questions.explanation: Cache clearing can free space temporarily; performance depends on broader factors like storage health, background processes, and OS updates.

questions.claim: Enabling multi-factor authentication reduces the risk of account takeover.
questions.explanation: MFA adds an additional verification step so stolen passwords alone are insufficient.

questions.claim: Phishing emails often imitate trusted brands’ appearance to trick users into revealing credentials.
questions.explanation: Attackers spoof logos, sender names, and layouts to increase credibility and click-throughs.

questions.claim: Using public Wi-Fi without HTTPS can expose sensitive data to interception.
questions.explanation: Unencrypted traffic can be observed by others on the same network; HTTPS protects content in transit.

questions.claim: Keeping software updated helps patch known security vulnerabilities.
questions.explanation: Vendors release fixes for CVEs; timely updates reduce the attack surface.

questions.claim: Using strong, unique passwords for each site lowers the risk from credential stuffing attacks.
questions.explanation: Unique credentials prevent a breach on one platform from unlocking accounts elsewhere.
